history.content:
Personally, I have done database work and didn't take 186: I just took a basic SQL programming class the summer before I came to Berkeley. Definitely didn't cover all that 186 covers and didn't go as deep, like learning about the core data structures beneath databases, but it did teach all of the "practical" aspects of databases and was a pretty light course. It allowed me to get part time position doing database related work like building reports and tools that interface with a large database, and even in my job I didn't use *all* of the stuff I learned in that course. I'd say SQL querying is pretty easy to self-teach as it's quite intuitive, and because there's so many SQL languages that differ slightly, you end up self teaching a lot anyway. The parts of the work that is a bit harder to self teach is database design and data definition (creating structures like tables, procedures, triggers, functions, etc. as there are many ways to go about these with varying efficiency). The hardest part (if you are working heavily or entirely with databases e.g. backend dev or database administrator) which in my experience is inevitable is getting acquainted with the database you will be working with, but this is something you can't really prepare for, it just happens, though being a good DB programmer makes this hurdle smaller.

From my SWE experience, having worked a lot with SQL and databases helped me get a SWE internship which involves backend web dev. work - people underestimate how often database knowledge will come in handy. It's not necessarily the case that most SWE jobs will involve lots of database programming, but its highly likely you will at least need to know how to write a query in some instances if you work for a company with lots of data (aka most companies).

186 is probably a good class to take if you want to go into SWE and you're already at Berkeley, but most likely you will only need a portion of the knowledge 186 imparts, 168 is also useful theoretical knowledge for database programming (packet sending, protocols, routing, etc are all beneath a lot of the SQL procedures that you might encounter) though it's probably overkill to know this stuff just for DB jobs, unless you become a DB engineer or something. 

TLDR: take 186 if you have time as at least SOME of the knowledge will be pretty useful and something you can definitely show off to companies. However, if you want to prioritize other stuff, self-studying database skills is definitely doable, though I recommend a light CC course when you have the chance because they'll probably do a good job teaching just the essential stuff.

I'm starting to feel a little concerned about not taking enough SWE courses. Usually i focus on material that's hard to self-study (123, 126, 170, 128, etc.) And if im ever interested in a more swe oriented class I could read books, do personal projects, etc.

If I ever wanted to do a backend databasey job, am I at a major disadvantage for not taking 186? I'd like to learn more about databases without having to sacrifice a class--is it simple (not easy) to learn it by myself or do I need to be in a class?
history.subject: How easy is it to learn 186 on your own?
